text: Pliné the Elder, a Roman author, naturalist, and philosopher, lived from 23 to 79 AD and is best known for his monumental work, Natural History, a vast encyclopedia covering all aspects of the natural world. Pliné's Natural History remains one of the most important sources on ancient agriculture, botany, and horticulture. He documented detailed descriptions of plants, their uses, and the farming practices of the time. His writings on crop rotation, soil health, and the medicinal properties of plants were groundbreaking and influenced farming techniques for centuries. Pliné emphasized the importance of understanding the land and nature, offering insights that are still relevant today. His work provided a foundation for the development of agronomy and gardening in Europe and beyond. Pliné's The Elder's Legacy lives on through his contributions to agriculture, making him a significant figure in the history of farming and gardening.
